headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question, I feel like I asked this question in many calls. Could you talk about maybe the timing of potential ruling for Moody's or kind of resolvement of the issue? And then where discussions are with CFPB?
componenttext: First question, I feel like I asked this question in many calls. Could you talk about maybe the timing of potential ruling for Moody's or kind of resolvement of the issue? And then where discussions are with CFPB?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the rating agency side, obviously, this has been on open item now for over a year. It's -- we're clearly disappointed in terms of the amount of time it's taking to get to a resolution. You know the challenge here is the cash flow aspects of th
componenttext: Sure. So on the rating agency side, obviously, this has been on open item now for over a year. It's -- we're clearly disappointed in terms of the amount of time it's taking to get to a resolution. You know the challenge here is the cash flow aspects of the federal student loans are fairly complex, there's over 56 different repayment options available to borrowers, including, I think, 9 income driven repayment solutions alone. And what we have seen historically is that while borrowers can, in fact, take advantage of multiple opportunities in some form of sequential fashion, that's actually not how the practice actually unfolds. And so I think the struggle has been what the customer -- what customers are eligible to do versus what they really do. And what we're seeing on the FFELP side of the equation as we see in our private loan is that as the portfolios season, borrowers grow, income their actual income and their income potential grows, and delinquencies fall and repayments increase. So we're looking to get the rating agencies to work with the rating agencies to get this issue resolved as quickly as possible. As we said in our comments, at this point, we decided to not wait for those resolutions and return to the FFELP ABS market. On the regulatory front, we continued to have ongoing dialogue with the entities. I think a lot of the issues and items are related to how borrowers access and understands the different programs that are available to them. We are a firm believer that the program turns and options are too many and too complex. But at the end of the day, we know that went 9 times out of 10, when we reach a delinquent customer, we're able to explain those options to them and get them into repayment plan that keeps them out of default. Our biggest challenge in preventing defaults and helping people enroll income driven programs is contact with the customer. Over 90% of the loans, federal loans that we service that do end up in default, and we are at a much smaller rate than all other servicers, not those customers do not respond to the extensive efforts that we make to reach them. And as you know, we can't help a delinquent customer take advantage of the opportunities that are available to them if we can't reach them.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you envision both of these issues being resolved over the next 6 months or so? Or is it more?
componenttext: Do you envision both of these issues being resolved over the next 6 months or so? Or is it more?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you're asking me what I wish and what were able to do, we're one side of the transaction and so we can't -- we have been very responsive to the rating agencies who provided them extensive amounts of data and analytics to help them along in their
componenttext: Well, if you're asking me what I wish and what were able to do, we're one side of the transaction and so we can't -- we have been very responsive to the rating agencies who provided them extensive amounts of data and analytics to help them along in their way, but we can't convene the meetings and take the votes. On the regulatory side of the equation, we're working aggressively with the regulators to make sure that they understand what we're doing, how we run our business and certainly, more than willing to work with them to improve their way the federal student loan program works and operates so that we produce better results, we and our peers in the industry produce better results. But I can't tell you when, we're one side of the transaction, I can't help -- I can't predict when all of these things unfold and resolved.

componenttext: Sure. This particular, the first deal was 1 that I think came in conjunction with the ABS transaction. The fact that we're able to get back to an ABS deal, I think opens the door for future transactions clearly because there was an avenue previously over the last year to be able to acquire portfolios unless you had access to term funding. So I think the fact that we returned to the ABS market with 2 ABS transactions will open the door to acquisitions, and I will remind you we did acquire an addition to the $1.1 billion portfolio. We did acquire another $400 million of loans. So I think once we get through this and get through the legal final maturity date issue, I think the opportunities for acquired portfolios will open up.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just a follow-up on the whole FFELP situation, the spreads of those transactions were still on the wider end, does it require kind of resolution by Moody's to get the spreads down? How do you think about that recognizing you'd, obviously, ratted ha
componenttext: Great. Just a follow-up on the whole FFELP situation, the spreads of those transactions were still on the wider end, does it require kind of resolution by Moody's to get the spreads down? How do you think about that recognizing you'd, obviously, ratted have it rather sooner, have you given any thoughts there?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we saw spreads tightened and there are tightening even without a resolution from the rating agency side. But your point is correct, I mean, we believe they will tighten it even further if we were able to close this issue. The legal final maturity
componenttext: I think we saw spreads tightened and there are tightening even without a resolution from the rating agency side. But your point is correct, I mean, we believe they will tighten it even further if we were able to close this issue. The legal final maturity date that we're embedding in new deals and the dates we're using to amend the deals is very long. And so we believe that is providing the protection to investors to make sure that the ratings will exist throughout the life of the bond. At the end of the day, what the rating agency assumptions are, however, don't really don't impact what that cash flow actually are in the transactions. We are confident based on the pavement activity that we see of our behavior that those maturity dates -- those legal final maturity dates are well in excess of what's required. The deals that we acquired, the portfolios, the 1.5 billion of FFELP loans that we acquired this quarter, reflect current spreads and funding cost and term ABS. So from our perspective, we believe we earned -- the earnings that we will generate from those transactions is similar spreads were tighter, we just believe that if the spreads tightened, we will see increased opportunities to buy loans, which is, obviously, what we're hoping for.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe could you just talk a little bit about where you would want to see unsecured spreads before you actually were kind of willing to issue unsecured debt because it just feels like you've done so much of vary sources of financing, but there
componenttext: Got it. And maybe could you just talk a little bit about where you would want to see unsecured spreads before you actually were kind of willing to issue unsecured debt because it just feels like you've done so much of vary sources of financing, but there seems to be some doubt, and I think that would probably put people's mind at ease and a bit more. Could you just discuss that a little?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think -- I don't -- I don't want to provide an exact level where we would be issuing here. I think the big opportunity for us is we don't need to borrow funds to grow our liability these, which is smooth out our unsecured debt maturities. To the ex
componenttext: Yes. I think -- I don't -- I don't want to provide an exact level where we would be issuing here. I think the big opportunity for us is we don't need to borrow funds to grow our liability these, which is smooth out our unsecured debt maturities. To the extent that spreads are unattractive, we just changes the timing of certain new cash flow distributions but it doesn't change the aggregate story. When we look at the financing transactions that we have done, particularly these private credit residual financing, those cost of funds are several hundreds of basis points inside where our unsecured debt levels trade in, and that's kind of the trade-offs we look at this, what's the opportunity between different alternatives there. Frankly, our biggest challenge right now is the -- is I think tells the story a little bit of where we see unsecured spreads going is buying unsecured debt in the open market. Our investors are telling us they're very happy with what they hold and not looking to sell. And that is the biggest challenge, but it also tells you that where the direction went where you go in spreads here.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to the last call that we had, and I just kind of want to kind of a reality check. Jack, you very forcibly opened up the call, basically saying that the reason I think up to this quarterly you had bought back about $1.3 billion in st
componenttext: I just want to go back to the last call that we had, and I just kind of want to kind of a reality check. Jack, you very forcibly opened up the call, basically saying that the reason I think up to this quarterly you had bought back about $1.3 billion in stock average price $17.20, the stock was hovering around 9 or 10, and you said the reason your returning money aggressively from share repurchase is because we agreed with those analysts to have value in the high-teens, actually you said low 20s, and this was a justification of the buyback. We kind of agreed with that, I'm just curious whether your view is similar, and that the $555 million remaining on your repurchase program that you plan to execute that this year, question 1, you're thinking about valuation and the repurchase program. And second, if there's an order of magnitude, I would think operating expenses ought to be lower, given the business is shrinking as we pay down loans, what kind of leverage is there to the shareholders from reduced operating expenses? Thank you.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee. Our view on the intrinsic value of the company is not changed. In fact, our ability to buy back 19.2 million shares at $10.42 actually increases that value for our remaining shareholders. And that's the type of activity that I said when we se
componenttext: Thanks, Lee. Our view on the intrinsic value of the company is not changed. In fact, our ability to buy back 19.2 million shares at $10.42 actually increases that value for our remaining shareholders. And that's the type of activity that I said when we see a mispriced market like these, we're trying to take advantage of that in order to add value to the base here, and we'll continue that process. We do expect to utilize our remaining authority in this year. We were a little frontloaded in the first quarter, taking advantage of what we saw as a very low or ridiculously low stock price and bought back more shares than kind of the pro rata portion there. On OpEx, first quarter's OpEx are always a little bit elevated because of basically taxes and compensation, taxes on compensation and compensation pay expenses that take place for the annual programs in February. So we do expect those numbers to come down. As I said, we fully expect to exit the year on a lower run rate than where we were -- where we entered the year for 2016. When we look at OpEx, some of the things that we do look at, we take a look at is not just the absolute levels, but where we're spending, what it cost us to perform different levels of activity. So that we're working to become more efficient in that side of the equation. I will say some of the areas that we are operating in have the fee income side of the equation have different ratios of OpEx to revenues than what you would see saying FFELP loan ownership versus FFELP federal loan servicing, as examples. But there's no question, we are working to try and become and continue our process and our success rate of becoming more efficient here. And as the FFELP and private loan portfolios amortize, you'll see those expenses decline.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the Department of Ed is interested in having all of its loans serviced on a single platform and the ERP at this stage in the game I would say is round one here is initial proposals and concepts. So terms and conditions are not set forth yet, and even t
componenttext: So the Department of Ed is interested in having all of its loans serviced on a single platform and the ERP at this stage in the game I would say is round one here is initial proposals and concepts. So terms and conditions are not set forth yet, and even the final business requirements are not established, so it's pretty mature to say what kind of impact this might have. Are we interested? Yes. I mean we are the largest servicer of federal loans. We have a system that is highly efficient, highly scalable, probably more importantly, highly automated. So that it's not just the IT operating infrastructure components, but what it means for the back-office servicing as well, and we look forward to responding to the ERP.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think the issue is here, what your cash flows look like in your debt maturities to ensure that you can repay your niche or your obligations without financing activities. componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Jessa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
Mr. Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessa. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2016 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, kee
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessa. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2016 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10-K and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of our core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the first quarter 2016 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted, along with the earnings press release, on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you. And now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. Our results for the first quarter are consistent with our plans. We earned an adjusted $0.44 in core earnings per share, with student loan margins and operating expenses in line with
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. Our results for the first quarter are consistent with our plans. We earned an adjusted $0.44 in core earnings per share, with student loan margins and operating expenses in line with expectations. Credit was a bright spot this quarter, and I will touch on this topic a bit more in a moment.
During the quarter, we continued to focus on several key areas: improving our access to and the cost of funding, delivering value to our customers and clients, capturing new business opportunities, improving our operating efficiency and growing the value of our company.
While the work in these areas is never complete, I'm pleased with our efforts, execution and results this quarter. We've been working on a number of fronts to address our access to funding and, specifically, funding for our government guaranteed FFELP assets. As you know, Moody's and Fitch have been reviewing their criteria for rating the term FFELP asset-backed loans. Unfortunately, to date, they have not issued any updated guidance.
While we currently believe that the final criteria will be more favorable than the initial draft proposals, we decided not to wait any longer to restart our FFELP ABS program. We completed our first FFELP ABS transaction in the first quarter, followed earlier this month with the second sale. Combined, we have now issued $1.6 billion in FFELP ABS bond, investor reception was good and, more importantly, even stronger in the second deal.
We also completed an extension of our FFELP conduit facility, pushing the maturity date out 1 year to 2018. This facility was also scheduled to decline to $7 billion in size.
Given the potential for FFELP portfolio purchases, we increased the size to $7.5 billion. And extending this facility and returning to the FFELP ABS market demonstrate the high quality of the FFELP portfolio and the confidence of lenders and investors in our securities.
We are also addressing the potential rating agency impacts on outstanding bonds. As of today, we have extended the legal final maturity date on $4.8 billion in bonds. While we believe the assumptions used to determine the new maturity date of these extensions are unnecessarily long, or said differently, we certainly expect the loans to pay off prior to the new maturity dates. We have worked with bondholders to extend the maturity date of their bonds in order to protect the value of their investment.
Also on the financing front, we completed a private loan securitization in the first quarter. And last week, we completed our second private credit residual financing. Combined, these transactions raised over $525 million in free cash. The proceeds will be used to further reduce our unsecured debt. Combined, our steady and significant financing activity ensures that we have ample liquidity to run our business, pursue portfolio acquisitions and increase the intrinsic value for shareholders.
As we all know, it's an election year, so student loan performance and indebtedness continues to be a regular political and media topic. The data reported here is often misleading, confusing and driven by anecdotes instead of facts. For example, it was recently reported that few student loan borrowers are making payments on their loans. The calculation here is complicated by the ways the program reports outstanding balances.
Unique to the federal loan program is that cumulative defaults are included in delinquency and repayment statistics since there's no charge-off for bad debt used by the federal government. This would be fine if the statistics also included the balances that were paid down, but they do not. As a result, borrowers who successfully repaid their loans are excluded from the analysis.
For the record, for loans we own, our customers are successfully making payments on their loans, having made over $3.6 billion in payments to principal in the first quarter. What we see from over 12 million customers, with over $300 billion in balances, is continued improvement in credit performance.
For our private loans, our 90-plus delinquency rate fell to 3.2% at March 31, down from 3.6% a year ago. And importantly, the dollar balance of loans over 90 days past due declined over 20% from a year ago to $749 million. The charge-off rate also improved, declining 17% from the year-ago quarter to 2.4%. And the performance this quarter and the reductions in delinquent dollar balances at quarter end are positive signs for the remainder of the year.
We continue to work to capture new business opportunities. During the quarter, we acquired $1.5 billion in FFELP Loans. We're beginning to see signs that opportunities to purchase additional student loan portfolios will increase.
Our processing business in the municipal and health care areas is also growing nicely. For example, we recently won a new multiyear contract in New Jersey as well as new contracts in Arizona, Pennsylvania, California and Mississippi, to name a few. And we expanded our health care receivable services to new hospitals in New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Wisconsin.
This month, the Department of Education issued an RFP for a single servicing platform. The request for proposal is just to provide a servicing platform, not loaning services. Our existing servicing contract extends into 2019. Our team here is actively engaged in evaluating the opportunity with respect to the system RFP.
Like most financial services entities, we're working to continuously improve our operating efficiency, and we have several initiatives underway to accelerate our pace here. We plan to exit 2016 with a lower run rate operating expense level than where we are today. This is another example of our efforts to add value for our clients and other stakeholders.
During the quarter, we purchased 19.2 million shares at an average price of $10.42, a level significantly below what we see as the intrinsic value of the company. Capturing the opportunity here allows us to increase the intrinsic value per share to non-selling shareholders.
Our stock price is up significantly from its low earlier this year. Still, it does not reflect the full value of the company as we see it. Our focus on funding, capturing new business opportunities, improving operating efficiency and taking advantage of a mispriced market has allowed us to add value. We'll continue this focus and execution going forward.
Now I'll turn the call over to Somsak for a deeper look at our financial results, and I look forward to taking your questions later. Sak?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll review the first quarter results before highlighting the recent financing activities that took place. I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation available on the company's webs
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll review the first quarter results before highlighting the recent financing activities that took place. I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation available on the company's website, beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.
In the first quarter, we reported adjusted core earnings per share of $0.44, which excludes regulatory-related costs during the quarter. Our first quarter adjusted operating expenses totaled $243 million versus $230 million a year ago. The increase in these expenses is related to the additional costs resulting from the acquisitions of Gila and Xtend Healthcare. Excluding the expenses associated with these acquisitions, operating expenses were lower -- 6% lower than a year ago. 
Let's turn to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. In the quarter, we acquired $1.5 billion of FFELP student loans. While many major holders continue to wait for the resolution from the rating agencies related to the legal final maturities, we are beginning to see renewed interest in portfolio sales as well as FFELP ABS transactions.
FFELP core earnings were $66 million in the first quarter of 2016 compared with $85 million in the first quarter of 2015. The decrease in FFELP core earnings was primarily a result of the lower FFELP balance compared to the prior year and a net interest margin of 81 basis points, which was in line with our expectations.
The FFELP net interest margin declined from the fourth quarter, due mainly to the seasonal impact of floor income rebates that occur during the first quarter of each year.
During the quarter, we did hedge an additional $295 million of floor income, bringing future hedge floor income to $1 billion. We're also seeing improving credit trends in our FFELP portfolio as demonstrated by the 17% improvement in our 90-day delinquency rate.
Let's now turn to Slide 6 for a review of our Private Education Loans segment. Core earnings in this segment decreased $16 million from the year-ago quarter to $61 million. The decline is primarily the result of the declining balance in our private education loan portfolio and lower net interest margin. The decline in NIM is partially offset by the $16 million reduction in our loan loss provision. This reduction came as a result of the improved credit performance that we continue to see in our delinquency forbearance and charge-off rates. Charge-offs declined $46 million or 24% from the prior year. The improved performance demonstrates the power of seasoning that we have seen in our portfolio.
Slide 7 highlights some of those improvements in our private education loan asset quality trends over the last 5 years. This portfolio is well seasoned, with 95% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments. Our first quarter charge-offs came in at 2.4%, and our total delinquency rate declined to 6.2%.
The chart on the bottom of the slide demonstrates the benefits improved performance is having on our average FICO scores. The nontraditional loans that we have in our portfolio today have improved their FICO scores by 35 points on average over the last 5 years. Today, these loans are nontraditional, and we expect to see continued year-over-year improvement in this segment of the portfolio.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our Business Services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $75 million in the quarter compared with $86 million in the first quarter of 2015. The decrease was primarily related to the expected decline in education-related revenues.
Our nonfederal student loan-related asset recovery revenues increased by $30 million from the year-ago quarter to $51 million. The increase in these revenues was primarily related to the additions of Gila and Xtend Healthcare in 2015.
As Jack noted, we have been leveraging our skills and platform to grow our nonfederal student loan-related businesses steadily over the last few quarters, and we continue to win additional contracts in this space.
On Slide 9, I'd like to highlight our recent financing activities that we completed so far in 2016. In the past 2 months, we have issued over $1.6 billion of FFELP asset-backed securities. A $1.1 billion 2016-1 transaction that took place in the first quarter was the largest FFELP securitization in over 2 years. This transaction was done in conjunction with the loan acquisition from a third party and was unique because we did not utilize any funding capacity for this transaction.
Last week, we closed on an additional $497 million FFELP securitization. This was the first broadly marketed FFELP transaction since June of last year. And this securitization was met by strong investment demand and included over 18 unique investors receiving allocation.
The Triple-A rated securities priced at a 1-month LIBOR plus 138 basis points with a weighted average life of 5.2 years. With rating agencies [indiscernible] concerns, both these transactions are structured with long legal final maturity dates and have date-specific full-turbo feature.
While we continue to wait for Moody's and Fitch to provide final ratings methodology, we've been actively extending the legal final maturity dates on various trusts. Just on Monday, we announced the maturity extension on $1.2 billion of bonds. And since December 2015, we have now extended the legal final maturity date on $4.8 billion of bonds.
As Jack mentioned earlier, we also increased and extended our FFELP ABCP facility. This facility's revolving period was extended to March 2018. The maximum financing amount, which was originally scheduled to step down to $7 billion, was increased to $7.5 billion. Facility extension and funding costs were consistent with our plan.
Not all of our activity was related to FFELP during the quarter. We also issued a $488 million private education loan ABS in January. And the Triple-A portion of this transaction is priced at 1-month LIBOR plus 231 basis points with a 4.9-year weighted average life.
On April 15, we added 3 trusts to our existing private education loan repurchase facility, providing an additional $478 million of financing. This facility allows us to borrow against the private student loan overcollateralization and our private education loan securitization. That gives a full-turbo repayment feature. The proceeds from these transactions will be used to pay down our unsecured debt.
On that front, our unsecured debt declined by $1 billion in the quarter to $14.2 billion outstanding at quarter end. And I'll note that over the last 15 months, we have reduced our unsecured debt outstanding by $3.3 billion or 19%.
So as you can see, we remain focused on reducing the total amount of unsecured debt outstanding and smoothing out the maturity profile to better match the predictable cash flows coming from our education loan portfolio.
In the quarter, we had repurchased 19.2 million shares for $200 million at an average price of $10.42. In the quarter end, we have a remaining authority of $555 million under our share repurchase authority. All of this activity was undertaken while maintaining a strong capital position and a tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x.
Finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded first quarter GAAP net income of $181 million or $0.53 per share, and that's compared with net income of $292 million or $0.72 per share in the first quarter 2015. The primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the marks related to our derivative positions, expenses related to the restructuring and reorganization and the income associated with SLM Bank that we spun from.
That concludes my remarks, and we'll open now the call to questions.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first part of that question, Eric. So as of today, we've got about $2.1 billion of O/C balances left in these tubo deals that we have not finished yet. However, those balances will grow over time. And by the time they reach their call date
componenttext: Let me take the first part of that question, Eric. So as of today, we've got about $2.1 billion of O/C balances left in these tubo deals that we have not finished yet. However, those balances will grow over time. And by the time they reach their call date, it's expected to grow to about $3.1 billion. And then the second piece of the question was related to the unsecured debt. Certainly, yes, we would like to access the unsecured debt market, but the cost right now is high level to be on the sources of financing that we can access. But certainly, we think that once we get through the legal final maturity issue and some of the other unknowns out there, we want to be able to access the unsecured market hopefully in the second half of the year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd just add to that, we have more than enough liquidity to meet and service our debt obligations here, including our peak maturity periods. What we really want to do is, as Somsak said, smooth out those items to create a little bit more flexibility for i
componenttext: I'd just add to that, we have more than enough liquidity to meet and service our debt obligations here, including our peak maturity periods. What we really want to do is, as Somsak said, smooth out those items to create a little bit more flexibility for it, particularly if we see opportunities to buy student loan portfolios. It's -- we are certainly pleased with the improvements we've seen in terms of access to funding and liquidity over the last -- both what we did in the fourth quarter of last year and what we were able to accomplish this quarter. The return to the FFELP ABS market is a good indication of the broadening of that access, and we'll continue to be opportunistic where we see those opportunities.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani from KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sanjay Sakhrani from KBW.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just the first question, I feel like I asked this question in many calls. Could you just talk about maybe the timing of potential ruling for Moody's or kind of resolvement of the issue and then where discussions are with CFPB?
componenttext: Just the first question, I feel like I asked this question in many calls. Could you just talk about maybe the timing of potential ruling for Moody's or kind of resolvement of the issue and then where discussions are with CFPB?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So on the rating agency side, obviously, this has been an open item now for over a year. It's -- we're clearly disappointed in terms of the amount of time it's taking to get to a resolution. The challenge here is the cash flow aspects of the federal
componenttext: Sure. So on the rating agency side, obviously, this has been an open item now for over a year. It's -- we're clearly disappointed in terms of the amount of time it's taking to get to a resolution. The challenge here is the cash flow aspects of the federal student loans are fairly complex. There's over 56 different repayment options available to borrowers, including, I think, 9 income-driven repayment solutions alone. And what we have seen historically is that while borrowers can, in fact, take advantage of multiple opportunities in some form of sequential fashion, that's actually not -- that's not how the practice actually unfolds. And so I think the struggle has been what the customer -- what customers are eligible to do versus what they really do. And what we're seeing on the FFELP side of the equation as we see in our private loan is that as the portfolios season, borrowers grow, their income -- their actual income and their income potential grows, and delinquencies fall and repayments increase. So we're looking to get the rating agencies -- to work with the rating agencies to get this issue resolved as quickly as possible. As we said in our comments, at this point in time, we decided to not wait for those resolutions and return to the FFELP ABS market. On the regulatory front, we continue to have ongoing dialogue with the entities. I think a lot of the issues and items are related to how borrowers access and understand the different programs that are available to them. We are a firm believer that the program terms and options are too many and too complex. But at the end of the day, we know that when 9 times out of 10, when we reach a delinquent customer, we're able to explain those options to them and get them into a repayment plan that keeps them out of default. Our biggest challenge in preventing defaults and helping people enroll in income-driven repayment programs is contact with the customer. Over 90% of the loans -- federal loans that we service, they do end up in default, and we are at a much smaller rate than all other servicers, not those customers do not respond to the extensive efforts we make to reach them. And as you know, we can't help a delinquent customer take advantage of the opportunities that are available to them if we can't reach them.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you envision any -- both of these issues being resolved over the next 6 months or so? Or is it more open-ended?
componenttext: Do you envision any -- both of these issues being resolved over the next 6 months or so? Or is it more open-ended?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, if you're asking me what I wish and what we're able to do, I mean, we're one side of the transaction, and so we can't -- we have been very responsive to the rating agencies. We provided them with extensive amounts of data and analytics to help them
componenttext: Well, if you're asking me what I wish and what we're able to do, I mean, we're one side of the transaction, and so we can't -- we have been very responsive to the rating agencies. We provided them with extensive amounts of data and analytics to help them along in their way, but we can't convene the meetings and take the votes. On the regulatory side of the equation, we're working aggressively with the regulators to make sure that they understand what we're doing, how we run our business and, certainly, more than willing to work with them to improve the way the federal student loan program works and operates so that we produce better results, we and our peers in the industry produce better results. But I can't tell you when. We're one side of the transaction. I can't help -- I can't predict when all of these things unfold and resolve.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair. One quick follow-up on -- for Somsak. I guess, Somsak, you mentioned the renewed interest in portfolio sales. Can you just talk about the nature of those M&A potential deals?
componenttext: That's fair. One quick follow-up on -- for Somsak. I guess, Somsak, you mentioned the renewed interest in portfolio sales. Can you just talk about the nature of those M&A potential deals?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. This particular -- the first deal was one that I think came with the -- came in conjunction with the ABS transaction. The fact that we're able to get back to an ABS deal I think opens the door for future transactions clearly because -- now there was
componenttext: Sure. This particular -- the first deal was one that I think came with the -- came in conjunction with the ABS transaction. The fact that we're able to get back to an ABS deal I think opens the door for future transactions clearly because -- now there was an avenue previously over the last year to be able to acquire portfolios unless you had access to term funding. So I think the fact that we returned to the ABS market with 2 ABS transactions will open the door to acquisitions. And I'll remind you, we did acquire -- in addition to the $1.1 billion portfolio, we did acquire another $400 million of loans. So I think once we get through this and then get through the legal final maturity date issue, I think the opportunities for acquired portfolios will open up.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to be clear, the motivation is still there by the larger banks to sell their portfolios, not to retain them.
componenttext: And to be clear, the motivation is still there by the larger banks to sell their portfolios, not to retain them.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes. As you know, right, the pricing will be partly determined by what the funding cost is to fund these assets. And if the cost of assets, the funding, is not there or the cost is elevated, it's going to impact the pricing that sellers might be will
componenttext: Yes. Yes. As you know, right, the pricing will be partly determined by what the funding cost is to fund these assets. And if the cost of assets, the funding, is not there or the cost is elevated, it's going to impact the pricing that sellers might be willing to accept.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Moshe Orenbuch from Crédit Suisse.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Just a follow-up on the whole FFELP situation. The spreads on those transactions were still on the wider end. Does it require the kind of resolution by Moody's to get the spreads down? How do you think about that recognizing -- you'd obviously rath
componenttext: Great. Just a follow-up on the whole FFELP situation. The spreads on those transactions were still on the wider end. Does it require the kind of resolution by Moody's to get the spreads down? How do you think about that recognizing -- you'd obviously rather have it sooner, but do you have any thoughts there?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we saw spreads tighten, and they are tightening even without a resolution from the rating agency side. But your point is correct, I mean, if we believe they would tighten even further, if we were able to close this issue. The legal final mat
componenttext: Well, I think we saw spreads tighten, and they are tightening even without a resolution from the rating agency side. But your point is correct, I mean, if we believe they would tighten even further, if we were able to close this issue. The legal final maturity date that we're embedding in new deals and the dates we're using to amend all deals is very long. And so we believe that is providing the protection to investors to make sure that the ratings will exist throughout the life of the bond. At the end of the day, what the rating agency assumptions are, however, don't really -- don't impact what the cash flows actually are in the transactions. And we are confident based on the payment activity that we see of our behavior that those maturity dates are -- those legal final maturity dates are well in excess of what's required. The deals that we acquired, the portfolios, the $1.5 billion of FFELP loans that we acquired this quarter, reflect current spreads and funding cost and term ABS. And so from our perspective, we believe we earn -- the earnings that we will generate from those transactions as similar spreads were tighter. We just believe that if spreads tighten, we will see increased opportunities to buy loans, which is obviously the -- what we're hoping for.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And maybe could you just talk a little bit about where you would want to see unsecured spreads before you actually were kind of willing to issue unsecured debt? Because it just feels like -- I mean, you've done so much of vary sources of financing
componenttext: Got it. And maybe could you just talk a little bit about where you would want to see unsecured spreads before you actually were kind of willing to issue unsecured debt? Because it just feels like -- I mean, you've done so much of vary sources of financing, but there still seems to be some doubt, and I think that would probably put people's mind at ease a little more. So could you just discuss that a little?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the -- I don't -- I'm not sure we want to provide an exact level where we would be issuing here. I think the big opportunity for us is we don't need to borrow funds to grow our liability days. We just want to smooth out our unsecured debt mat
componenttext: Yes. I think the -- I don't -- I'm not sure we want to provide an exact level where we would be issuing here. I think the big opportunity for us is we don't need to borrow funds to grow our liability days. We just want to smooth out our unsecured debt maturities. So to the extent that spreads are unattractive, we -- it just changes the timing of certain new cash flow distributions, but it doesn't change the aggregate story. When we look at the financing transactions that we have done, particularly these private credit residual financing, those cost of funds are several hundreds of basis points inside where our unsecured debt levels trade in, and that's kind of the trade-off we will look at, what's the opportunity between different alternatives there. Frankly, our biggest challenge right now is the -- and this, I think, tells the story a little bit about where we see unsecured spreads going, is buying unsecured debt in the open market. Our investors are telling us they're very happy with what they hold and not looking to sell. And that is the biggest challenge. But it also tells you that the -- where the direction likely to go in spreads here.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: They've mostly been answered. I'll make an observation as a question. It does feel like in the last 3 months, the environment has changed immeasurably. And I think it's interesting that I think throughout this, you guys have just sort of consistently done the same thing, and I think that's a good sign. I'd love to talk a little bit more, following up on what Sanjay and Moshe asked, about the FFELP markets. My takeaway from what you just said is that the pricing on asset sales has recalibrated so that the returns on those deals are very different for you from what you've experienced historically. I am curious -- you talked about the spread on the $1.1 billion deal you did last quarter. I'm curious where pricing was on the second deal.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back to the last call that we had, and I just want to kind of do a reality check. Jack, you very forcibly -- forcefully opened up the call, basically saying that the reason -- I think up until this quarter, you had bought back about $1.3
componenttext: I just want to go back to the last call that we had, and I just want to kind of do a reality check. Jack, you very forcibly -- forcefully opened up the call, basically saying that the reason -- I think up until this quarter, you had bought back about $1.3 billion in stock, average price pays $17.20. The stock was hovering around $9 or $10. And you said that the reason we're returning money aggressively from share repurchase is because we agree with those analysts to have a value in the high teens. Actually, you said low 20s. And this was a justification of the buyback. We kind of agree with that. I'm just curious whether your view is similar and that the $555 million remaining on your repurchase program that your plan is to execute that this year. That'd be question one. Just kind of update us on your thinking about valuation and the repurchase program. And second, if this is an order of magnitude, I would think operating expenses would have been lower given that this -- the business is shrinking as we pay down loans. What kind of leverage is there to the shareholders from reduced operating expenses?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lee. So our view on the intrinsic value of the company is not changed. In fact, our ability to buy back 19.2 million shares at $10.42 actually increases that value for the remaining shareholders. And that's the type of activity that I said when we
componenttext: Thanks, Lee. So our view on the intrinsic value of the company is not changed. In fact, our ability to buy back 19.2 million shares at $10.42 actually increases that value for the remaining shareholders. And that's the type of activity that I said when we see a mispriced market like this, we're trying to take advantage of that in order to add value to the base here. And we'll continue that process. We do expect to utilize our remaining authority in this year. We were a little front-loaded in the first quarter, taking advantage of what we saw as a very low or ridiculously low stock price and bought back more shares than kind of the pro rata portion there. On OpEx, first quarter's OpEx are always a little bit elevated because of, basically, taxes and compensation -- taxes on compensation and compensation pay expenses that take place for the annual programs in February. So we do expect those numbers to come down. And as I said, we fully expect to exit the year on a lower run rate than where we were -- where we entered the year for 2016. When we look at OpEx, some of the things that we do look at, we take a look at, is not just the absolute levels but where we're spending, what it costs us to perform different levels of activity, so that we're working to become more efficient in that side of the equation. I will say some of the areas that we are operating in have -- the fee income side of the equation have different ratios of OpEx to revenues than what you would see, say, in FFELP loan ownership versus FFELP -- versus federal loan servicing, as examples. But there's no question, we are working to try and become -- and continue our process and our success rate of becoming more efficient here. And as the FFELP and private loan portfolios amortize, you'll see those expenses decline.

componenttext: So on the servicing side, regarding that single servicer portal RFP, just curious, do you have a sense for what kind of impact that could have on the business? And then is that a contract that you could theoretically bid on or would be interested in even though you're still one of that servicers?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the Department of Ed is interested in having all of its loans serviced on a single platform. And the RFP at this stage in the game, I would say, is -- round one here is initial proposals and concepts. So terms and conditions are not set forth yet, and
componenttext: So the Department of Ed is interested in having all of its loans serviced on a single platform. And the RFP at this stage in the game, I would say, is -- round one here is initial proposals and concepts. So terms and conditions are not set forth yet, and even the final business requirements are not established, so it's premature to say what kind of impact this might have. Are we interested? Yes. I mean, we are the largest servicer of federal loans. We have a system that is highly efficient, highly scalable, probably more importantly, highly automated, so that it's not just the IT operating infrastructure components but what it means for the back-office servicing as well. And we look forward to responding to the RFP.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then from a prepayment perspective, are you seeing any major changes in loans that are getting consolidated away from you guys? It seems like that may have picked up a little bit this quarter.
componenttext: Okay. And then from a prepayment perspective, are you seeing any major changes in loans that are getting consolidated away from you guys? It seems like that may have picked up a little bit this quarter.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you know, the repaying program was launched last quarter, fourth quarter, and there was a small increase in prepayments for customers who needed to move into the direct loan program in order to be eligible for that income-driven repayment solution.
componenttext: So as you know, the repaying program was launched last quarter, fourth quarter, and there was a small increase in prepayments for customers who needed to move into the direct loan program in order to be eligible for that income-driven repayment solution. But for borrowers who are eligible for some of the other repayment -- income-based repayment solutions, they are usually better programs because they have shorter repayment terms but larger balance accounts. So we don't expect to see any more significant increase here. We already have a higher -- a high percentage of our customers that are in repayment signed up for income-driven repayment solutions as well. We've been actively marketing and promoting this program for a number of years. And again, for borrowers who signed up for those programs, they're generally better off persisting in them rather than converting to a new one.

componenttext: Okay. And then just last couple of modeling ones. Are you still expecting NIM on FFELP in the low to mid-80s and then private in the mid-350s for the year? componenttext: Okay. So let me provide a breakdown of -- unencumbered assets and O/C are 2 different things. Today, we've got a little over $700 million of unencumbered FFELP, well under $4 billion of unencumbered private. But in terms of our private credit O/Cs that are tied to our turbo deals, today, we've got $2.1 billion of balance that we can continue to finance. But that balance is expected to grow over the time and is expected to go to about $3.1 billion by the time that we gauge the call date for those particular deals.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And is that the primary source of liquidity you could tap as you look towards smoothing out the kind of chunky 2017 unsecured debt maturity coming up?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- yes, those are the primary sources we've been tapping. Remember that we've been accessing these resources of liquidity that we have an access in the past. We know there were some questions about whether we could access them. I think the activi
componenttext: Well, we -- yes, those are the primary sources we've been tapping. Remember that we've been accessing these resources of liquidity that we have an access in the past. We know there were some questions about whether we could access them. I think the activities we entered into over the last few quarters, including the ventures, that we've been able to access those. And I think between that and the cash flows that we generate from our operations give everyone confidence that we are going to be able to service our unsecured debt, and then, obviously, we want to be able to access unsecured debt going forward to provide flexibility, to continue to grow our business going forward.

componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up question. So Moody's has written about a $4 billion unencumbered asset threshold that has gone below that could prompt a ratings downgrade on the unsecured. At the end of the quarter, unencumbered student loans had totaled up $3.8 billion. S&P has seemed to flag something like this as well. Have you had any recent conversations with the rating agencies, not on the FFELP ABS but actually just on the unsecured ratings?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the issues here are what do your cash flows look like in your debt maturities to ensure that you can repay your niche or obligations without financing activities. And one of the things that we've been clear in our comments and analysis that
componenttext: Well, I think the issues here are what do your cash flows look like in your debt maturities to ensure that you can repay your niche or obligations without financing activities. And one of the things that we've been clear in our comments and analysis that we're providing to the rating agencies is that we have sufficient cash flows to service our debt maturities as they occur. And that's the kind of the critical component here. So if one were to encumber the unencumbered loans and use the proceeds for something other than debt service, I could see where that might be a concern. But if you were to encumber the loans and pay down the debt, I'm not sure why that changes the credit profile of the company. Well, I know it would not change the credit profile.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: As a matter of fact, it would then -- just going through that exercise actually improves our net tangible assets on profit [ph] ratio.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jessa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.Mr. Joe Fisher, Vice President of
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Jessa, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Navient First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
Mr. Joe Fisher, Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin your conference.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jessa. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2016 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.Before we begin, kee
componenttext:
Thank you, Jessa. Good morning, and welcome to Navient's 2016 First Quarter Earnings Call. With me today are Jack Remondi, our CEO; and Somsak Chivavibul, our CFO. After their prepared remarks, we will open up the call for questions.
Before we begin, keep in mind our discussion will contain predictions, expectations and forward-looking statements. Actual results in the future may be materially different from those discussed here. This could be due to a variety of factors. Listeners should refer to the discussion of those factors on the company's Form 10-K and other filings with the SEC.
During this conference call, we will refer to non-GAAP measures we call our core earnings. A description of our core earnings, a full reconciliation to GAAP measures and our GAAP results can be found in the first quarter 2016 supplemental earnings disclosure. This is posted, along with the earnings press release, on the Investors page at navient.com.
Thank you. And now I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. Our results for the first quarter are consistent with our plans. We earned an adjusted $0.44 in core earnings per share, with student loan margins and operating expenses in line with
componenttext:
Thanks, Joe. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. Our results for the first quarter are consistent with our plans. We earned an adjusted $0.44 in core earnings per share, with student loan margins and operating expenses in line with expectations. Credit was a bright spot this quarter, and I will touch on this topic a bit more in a moment.
During the quarter, we continued to focus on several key areas: improving our access to and the cost of funding, delivering value to our customers and clients, capturing new business opportunities, improving our operating efficiency and growing the value of our company.
While the work in these areas is never complete, I'm pleased with our efforts, execution and results this quarter. We've been working on a number of fronts to address our access to funding and, specifically, funding for our government guaranteed FFELP assets. As you know, Moody's and Fitch have been reviewing their criteria for rating term FFELP asset-backed bonds. Unfortunately, to-date, they have not issued any updated guidance.
While we currently believe that the final criteria will be more favorable than the initial draft proposals, we've decided not to wait any longer to restart our FFELP ABS program. We completed our first FFELP ABS transaction in the first quarter, followed earlier this month with a second sale. Combined, we have now issued $1.6 billion in FFELP ABS bonds, investor reception was good and, more importantly, even stronger in the second deal.
We also completed an extension of our FFELP conduit facility, pushing the maturity date out 1 year to 2018. This facility was also scheduled to decline to $7 billion in size.
Given the potential for FFELP portfolio purchases, we increased the size to $7.5 billion. And extending this facility and returning to the FFELP ABS market demonstrate the high quality of the FFELP portfolio and the confidence of lenders and investors in our securities.
We are also addressing the potential rating agency impacts on outstanding bonds. As of today, we have extended the legal final maturity date on $4.8 billion in bonds. While we believe the assumptions used to determine the new maturity date of these extensions are unnecessarily long, or said differently, we certainly expect the loans to pay off prior to the new maturity dates, we have worked with bondholders to extend the maturity date of their bonds in order to protect the value of their investment.
Also on the financing front, we completed a private loan securitization in the first quarter. And last week, we completed our second private credit residual financing. Combined, these transactions raised over $525 million in free cash. The proceeds will be used to further reduce our unsecured debt. Combined, our steady and significant financing activity ensures that we have ample liquidity to run our business, pursue portfolio acquisitions and increase the intrinsic value for shareholders.
As we all know, it's an election year, so student loan performance and indebtedness continues to be a regular political and media topic. The data reported here is often misleading, confusing and driven by anecdotes instead of facts. For example, it was recently reported that few student loan borrowers are making payments on their loans. The calculation here is complicated by the way the program reports outstanding balances.
Unique to the federal loan program is that cumulative defaults are included in delinquency and repayment statistics since there's no charge-off for bad debt used by the federal government. This would be fine if the statistics also included the balances that were paid down, but they do not. As a result, borrowers who successfully repaid their loans are excluded from the analysis.
For the record, for loans we own, our customers are successfully making payments on their loans, having made over $3.6 billion in payments to principal in the first quarter. What we see from over 12 million customers, with over $300 billion in balances, is continued improvement in credit performance.
For our private loans, our 90-plus delinquency rate fell to 3.2% at March 31, down from 3.6% a year ago. And importantly, the dollar balance of loans over 90 days past due declined over 20% from a year ago to $749 million. The charge-off rate also improved, declining 17% from the year-ago quarter to 2.4%. And the performance this quarter and the reductions in delinquent dollar balances at quarter end are positive signs for the remainder of the year.
We continue to work to capture new business opportunities. During the quarter, we acquired $1.5 billion in FFELP Loans. We're beginning to see signs that opportunities to purchase additional student loan portfolios will increase.
Our processing business in the municipal and health care areas is also growing nicely. For example, we recently won a new multiyear contract in New Jersey as well as new contracts in Arizona, Pennsylvania, California and Mississippi, to name a few. And we expanded our health care receivable services to new hospitals in New Hampshire, Pennsylvania, Maryland and Wisconsin.
This month, the Department of Education issued an RFP for a single servicing platform. The request for proposals is to provide a servicing platform, not loan services. Our existing servicing contract extends into 2019. Our team here is actively engaged in evaluating the opportunity with respect to the system RFP.
Like most financial services entities, we're working to continuously improve our operating efficiency, and we have several initiatives underway to accelerate our pace here. We are planning to exit 2016 with a lower run rate operating expense level than where we are today. This is another example of our efforts to add value for our clients and other stakeholders.
During the quarter, we purchased 19.2 million shares at an average price of $10.42, a level significantly below what we see as the intrinsic value of the company. Capturing the opportunity here allows us to increase the intrinsic value per share to non-selling shareholders.
Our stock price is up significantly from its low earlier this year. Still, it does not reflect the full value of the company as we see it. Our focus on funding, capturing new business opportunities, improving operating efficiency and taking advantage of a mispriced market has allowed us to add value. We'll continue this focus and execution going forward.
Now I'll turn the call over to Somsak for a deeper look at our financial results, and I look forward to taking your questions later. Sak?

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll review the first quarter results before highlighting recent financing activities that took place. I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation available on the company's website,
componenttext:
Thanks, Jack. Good morning, everyone. During my prepared remarks, I'll review the first quarter results before highlighting recent financing activities that took place. I'll be referencing the earnings call presentation available on the company's website, beginning with Slide 4, which provides a summary of our core earnings.
In the first quarter, we reported adjusted core earnings per share of $0.44, which excludes regulatory-related costs during the quarter. Our first quarter adjusted operating expenses totaled $243 million versus $230 million a year ago. The increase in these expenses is related to the additional costs resulting from the acquisitions of Gila and Xtend Healthcare. Excluding the expenses associated with these acquisitions, operating expenses were lower -- 6% lower than a year ago. 
Let's turn to Slide 5 to discuss our FFELP segment results. In the quarter, we acquired $1.5 billion of FFELP student loans. While many major holders continue to wait for the resolution from the rating agencies related to the legal final maturities, we are beginning to see renewed interest in portfolio sales as well as FFELP ABS transactions.
FFELP core earnings were $66 million in the first quarter of 2016 compared with $85 million in the first quarter of 2015. The decrease in FFELP core earnings was primarily a result of lower FFELP balance compared to the prior year and a net interest margin of 81 basis points, which was in line with our expectations.
The FFELP net interest margin declined from the fourth quarter, due mainly to the seasonal impact of floor income rebates that occur during the first quarter of each year.
During the quarter, we did hedge an additional $295 million of floor income, bringing future hedge floor income to $1 billion. We're also seeing improving credit trends in our FFELP portfolio as demonstrated by the 17% improvement in our 90-day delinquency rate.
Let's now turn to Slide 6 for a review of our Private Education Loan segment. Core earnings in this segment decreased $16 million from the year-ago quarter to $61 million. The decline is primarily the result of the declining balance in our private education loan portfolio and lower net interest margin. The decline in NIM is partially offset by the $16 million reduction in our loan loss provision. This reduction came as a result of the improved credit performance that we continue to see in our delinquency forbearance and charge-off rates. Charge-offs declined $46 million or 24% from the prior year. The improved performance demonstrates the power of seasoning that we have seen in our portfolio.
Slide 7 highlights some of those improvements in our private education loan asset quality trends over the last 5 years. This portfolio is well seasoned, with 95% of our loans in repayment status having made more than 12 payments. Our first quarter charge-offs came in at 2.4%, and our total delinquency rate declined to 6.2%.
The chart on the bottom of the slide demonstrates the benefits improved performance is having on our orawis [ph] FICO scores. The nontraditional loans that we have in our portfolio today have improved their FICO scores by 35 points on average over the last 5 years. Today, these loans are nontraditional in name only, and we expect to see continued year-over-year improvement in this segment of the portfolio.
Let's turn to Slide 8 to review our Business Services segment. In this segment, core earnings were $75 million in the quarter compared with $86 million in the first quarter of 2015. The decrease was primarily related to the expected decline in education-related revenues.
Our nonfederal student loan-related asset recovery revenues increased by $30 million from the year-ago quarter to $51 million. The increase in these revenues was primarily related to the additions of Gila and Xtend Healthcare in 2015.
As Jack noted, we have been leveraging our skills and platform to grow our nonfederal student loan-related businesses steadily over the last few quarters, and we continue to win additional contracts in this space.
On Slide 9, I'd like to highlight our recent financing activities that we completed so far in 2016. In the past 2 months, we have issued over $1.6 billion of FFELP asset-backed securities. A $1.1 billion 2016-1 transaction that took place in the first quarter was the largest FFELP securitization in over 2 years. This transaction was done in conjunction with a loan acquisition from a third party and was unique because we did not utilize any funding capacity for this transaction.
Last week, we closed on an additional $497 million FFELP securitization. This was the first broadly-marketed FFELP transaction since June of last year. And this securitization was met by strong investment demand and included over 18 unique investors receiving allocations.
The Triple-A rated securities priced at a 1-month LIBOR plus 138 basis points with a weighted average life of 5.2 years. With rack rating agencies extension [ph] concerns, both these transactions are structured with long legal final maturity dates and a date-specific full-turbo feature.
While we continue to wait for Moody's and Fitch to provide final ratings methodology, we've been actively extending the legal final maturity dates on various trusts. Just on Monday, we announced the maturity extension on $1.2 billion of bonds. And since December 2015, we have now extended the legal final maturity date on $4.8 billion of bonds.
As Jack mentioned earlier, we also increased and extended our FFELP ABCP facility. This facility's revolving period was extended to March 2018. The maximum financing amount, which was originally scheduled to step down to $7 billion, was increased to $7.5 billion. Facility extension and funding costs were consistent with our plan.
Not all of our activity was related to FFELP during the quarter. We also issued a $488 million private education loan ABS in January. And the Triple-A portion of this transaction priced at 1-month LIBOR plus 231 basis points with a 4.9-year weighted average life.
On April 15, we added 3 trusts to our existing private education loan repurchase facility, providing an additional $478 million of financing. This facility allows us to borrow against the private student loan overcollateralization and our private education loan securitization, benefit a full-turbo repayment feature. The proceeds from these transactions will be used to pay down our unsecured debt.
On that front, our unsecured debt declined by $1 billion in the quarter to $14.2 billion outstanding at quarter end. And I'll note that over the last 15 months, we have reduced our unsecured debt outstanding by $3.3 billion or 19%.
So as you can see, we remain focused on reducing the total amount of unsecured debt outstanding and smoothing out the maturity profile to better match the predictable cash flows coming from our education loan portfolio.
In the quarter, we repurchased 19.2 million shares for $200 million at an average price of $10.42. In the quarter end, we have a remaining authority of $555 million under our share repurchase authority. All of this activity was undertaken while maintaining a strong capital position and a tangible net asset ratio of 1.25x.
Finally, turning to GAAP results on Slide 10. We recorded first quarter GAAP net income of $181 million or $0.53 per share, and that's compared with net income of $292 million or $0.72 per share in the first quarter 2015. The primary differences between core earnings and GAAP results are the marks related to our derivative positions, expenses related to the restructuring and reorganization and the income associated with SLM Bank that we spun from.
That concludes my remarks, and we'll open now the call to questions.

componenttext: Still, obviously, it's just the first quarter, but the trends here are positive. I think the big number to look at is the amount that is in the 90-day-plus delinquency balance. So $749 million gives you an indication of what -- the potential of what's available, in effect, the default over the next 9 months. But we are -- we're keeping our guidance the same here, and we'd certainly look to benefit from better performance than expected.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just lastly, after you did the latest private loan O/C deal, how much capacity left do you have in those turbo loans to do similar deals? If you could just talk about your appetite to issue unsecured debt still for the rest of the year.
componenttext: Got it. And then just lastly, after you did the latest private loan O/C deal, how much capacity left do you have in those turbo loans to do similar deals? If you could just talk about your appetite to issue unsecured debt still for the rest of the year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me take the first part of that question, Eric. So as of today, we've got about $2.1 billion of O/C balances left in these turbo deals that we have not finished yet. However, those balances will grow over time. And by the time they reach their call dat
componenttext: Let me take the first part of that question, Eric. So as of today, we've got about $2.1 billion of O/C balances left in these turbo deals that we have not finished yet. However, those balances will grow over time. And by the time they reach their call date, it's expected to grow to about $3.1 billion. And then the second piece of the question was related to unsecured debt. Certainly, yes, we would like to access the unsecured debt market, but the cost right now is high level to do other sources of community [ph] that we can access. But certainly, we think that once we get through the legal final maturity issue and some of the other unknowns out there, we want to be able to access the unsecured market hopefully in the second half of the year.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd just add to that, we have more than enough liquidity to meet and service our debt obligations here, including our peak maturity periods. What we really want to do is, as Somsak said, smooth out those items to create a little bit more flexibility for u
componenttext: I'd just add to that, we have more than enough liquidity to meet and service our debt obligations here, including our peak maturity periods. What we really want to do is, as Somsak said, smooth out those items to create a little bit more flexibility for us, particularly if we see opportunities to buy student loan portfolios. It's -- we are certainly pleased with the improvements we've seen in terms of access to funding and liquidity over the last -- both what we did in the fourth quarter of last year and what we were able to accomplish this quarter. The return to the FFELP ABS market is a good indication of the broadening of that access, and we'll continue to be opportunistic where we see those opportunities.

headline: Navient Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
